metadata.case_name: Jugal Kishore & Amar Nath v. Dhiyan Singh & Jai Bhagwan Singh

facts.text: Megh Raj Singh is the common ancestor. Family tree: Megh Raj Singh had sons Jawahar Singh, Madan Singh, Shanker Lal (d. 1884). Shanker Lal had daughter Mst. Mohan Dei (d. Oct. 1929). Mst. Mohan Dei's husband Narain Das (d. 21-5-1940). Mst. Mohan Dei's son Shri Kishan Das (d. March 1929). Brijlal (d. 1890, plaintiffs' grandfather, son of Jawahar Singh?). Brijlal's sons: Kishan Lal, Mahabir Prasad (d. 1921). Kishan Lal's sons: Jugal Kishore (Plff 1), Amar Nath (Plff 2). Mst. Mohan Dei's grandsons: Dhiyan Singh (Deft. 1), Jai Bhagwan Singh (Deft. 2), Ghas Ram, Onkar Prasad.
Two branches of family were separate at all material times.
Dispute concerns property forming part of Shanker Lal's estate.

On Shanker Lal's death in 1884, daughter Mst. Mohan Dei succeeded to a limited estate. Reversion opened on her death in Oct. 1929. Shri Kishan Das predeceased her. Plaintiffs entitled as next reversioners.
Defendants' grandmother Mst. Mohan Dei possessed properties: some purchased/obtained under mortgages in her own right; others belonged exclusively to her father Shanker Lal.
On Shanker Lal's death, disputes arose between Brijlal (plaintiffs' grandfather) and Mst. Mohan Dei. Brijlal claimed entire estate by survivorship, alleging jointness and joint family properties.
Dispute referred to arbitration. Award (Ex. A-1) dated 21-12-1884: Mst. Mohan Dei given suit properties as absolute owner (malik mustaqil); rest to Brijlal. Division effected accordingly.
From 21-12-1884 to 26-3-1941 (suit date), each branch in separate uninterrupted possession, dealing as absolute owners.
Plaintiffs lost in first court, won in High Court. Defendants appeal to Supreme Court.
Award findings: Properties claimed by Mst. Mohan Dei as her own belonged to Shanker Lal (benami). Some properties ancestral, rest self-acquired.
Arbitrator's view of Hindu law: Brother owner of joint ancestral property; daughter with male issue owner of self-acquired property.
Brijlal's sons Kishan Lal and brother took possession under award, partitioned, sold parts to third parties.
Mst. Mohan Dei gifted suit property to grandsons (defendants) on 4th April 1929. Mutation effected, no objection by Kishan Lal.
Shri Kishan Das died March 1929, making Kishan Lal next presumptive reversioner.
D.W. 2 Dhiyan Singh testified Kishan Lal always accepted and acted on award; objection if any was after Mohan Dei's death.

legal_issues.text: Whether the award gave Mst. Mohan Dei an absolute estate or only a limited estate.
Whether plaintiffs are bound by the award or estopped from challenging it.

petitioner_arguments.text: Mst. Mohan Dei obtained only limited estate under award, not absolute. Award must be viewed as whole; earlier passages show intention for limited estate.
Arbitrator exceeded reference by awarding absolute interest. Kishan Lal had independent reversioner title, not bound by award; plaintiffs not bound.

respondent_arguments.text: Award gave Mst. Mohan Dei absolute estate (malik mustaqil). Plaintiffs bound by award and estopped.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Ram Gopal v. Nand Lal (1950 S.C.R. 766); Bishunath Prasad Singh v. Chandika Prasad Kumari (1933 60 I.A. 56)

respondent_arguments.text: Properties divided into those belonging to Mohan Dei and those from father.

court_reasoning.text: Award's operative portion clearly gives absolute estate using 'malik mustaqil'. Earlier passages do not qualify it unambiguously. Arbitrator confused on facts/law, but words clear.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Words admit no doubt; interpret in usual sense.

court_reasoning.text: No need to examine award binding nature; estoppel applies even if invalid.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Brijlal's conduct induced Mohan Dei to accept award, parting with property to her detriment.

court_reasoning.text: Estoppel against Brijlal: Serious claim to estate, accepted award dividing it, enjoyed benefits.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Representation of existing facts giving absolute estate.

court_reasoning.text: Estoppel descends to sons (Kishan Lal et al.): Claimed through father, no independent title, enjoyed benefits for 40 years, no objection to gifts/mutations.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Independent estoppel in Kishan Lal by possession, partition, sales.

court_reasoning.text: Estoppel continues post-reversion opening: Kishan Lal bound in new character as reversioner; plaintiffs through him.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Similar to Kanhai Lal v. Brij Lal; distinguishes Rangasami Gounden and Mt. Binda Kuer.

holdings.text: Award conferred absolute estate on Mst. Mohan Dei.
Plaintiffs estopped from claiming as reversioners due to conduct of Brijlal and Kishan Lal.

precedents_cited.relevance: Meaning of 'malik mustaqil' as absolute owner.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bishunath Prasad Singh v. Chandika Prasad Kumari

precedents_cited.relevance: Estoppel binds consenting reversioner even in new character after compromise/award acceptance.
Party benefiting from transaction estopped from questioning it.
Distinguished on facts re: independent title and benefit attribution.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mt. Binda Kuer v. Lalitha Prasad
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinguished; no clear benefit from compromise traceable to disputed share.

outcome.summary: Appeal succeeds. Decree of High Court set aside, decree of first court dismissing plaintiffs' claim restored.

key_quotes.text: 'each party has become permanent owner malik mustaqil of his or her share'
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Operative portion of award conferring absolute estate.

key_quotes.text: 'We do not think the words admit of any doubt, particularly as the words malik mustaqil have been used'
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: 'Kishanlal always accepted this award and acted upon it'
key_quotes.speaker: respondent_counsel
key_quotes.significance: Testimony supporting estoppel against Kishan Lal.
